episode.title: Cariboo Signals - Indigenous Lands & Innovation
episode.description: Riley and Casey explore technology and society in rural communities. Today's focus: Indigenous Lands & Innovation. NEWS ROUNDUP: We break down [Nautilus] Space Age Technology Reveals Secrets of Bronze Age Sword and [Quesnel Cariboo Observer] B.C. quietly suspends major affordable housing fund, leaving proponents holding the bag, plus 1 more stories, and explore what these developments mean for communities like ours. RURAL CONNECTIONS: Can Indigenous communities use technology to shift power relationships and control innovation processes, or are they being forced to innovate around systemic problems while facing extractive timelines? Topics include: Digital preservation and cultural knowledge documentation, Critical minerals extraction vs Indigenous consent processes, Indigenous-controlled technology infrastructure requirements, Scale mismatches between community governance and global commodity timelines, Technology as a tool for shifting power relationships rather than just responding to them. Hosts: Riley (Tech optimist with an engineering background) and Casey (Community-first skeptic of tech promises). Sources discussed: 1. discussion.central_question: Can Indigenous communities use technology to shift power relationships and control innovation processes, or are they being forced to innovate around systemic problems while facing extractive timelines?
discussion.riley_position: Indigenous communities can lead innovation by controlling technology development from the start, using tools like blockchain, digital governance platforms, and environmental monitoring to strengthen self-determination and shift power dynamics.
riley_key_evidence: Coast Salish artists using traditional and digital media for visual storytelling systems
Himalayan communities using traditional ice harvesting with modern materials for glacier grafting
Indigenous communities building blockchain registries and peer-to-peer networks for knowledge preservation
discussion.casey_position: While Indigenous-led innovation has potential, communities face structural power imbalances with government and industry operating on faster timelines, forcing reactive responses rather than genuine control over development.
casey_key_evidence: BC's accelerated critical minerals extraction without meaningful Indigenous consent
Premier Eby's comments about reconciliation legislation being 'in the way' of economic development
Communities being asked to make decisions about projects with decades-long implications under rushed consultation processes
discussion.resolution: Both agreed that Indigenous technological sovereignty should be a prerequisite for resource development, with funding from industry, and concluded by asking listeners what Indigenous-led innovation would look like specifically in Cariboo communities.
